title: MOFCOM provides RMB 27 million grant for Earthquake Observation and Measurement and Tsunami Early-Warning System Project
description: In March 2005, the Chinese Government and the Government of Indonesia signed a grant agreement for the Earthquake Observation and Measurement and Tsunami Early-Warning System Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) was the source of funding and it reportedly committed RMB 27 million in total.   The purpose of the project was to build an earthquake and tsunami early-warning system. The system consisted of 10 seismograph broadband and accelerometers and a national tsunami warning center. It involved station construction, equipment installation, technical services, spare parts maintenance, processing facilities, training, and expertise for a limited time to the Indonesian government. China Earthquake Administration was responsible for project implementation, which began in 2006 and ended in March 2009. The project was officially handed over to the Indonesian government on April 12, 2010.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Indonesia-China Digital Seismograph Network (ICDSN) Project. The Chinese project title is 印尼地震海啸预警台网 or 援印尼地震监测和海啸预警系统项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
MOFCOM provides RMB 27 million grant for Earthquake Observation and Measurement and Tsunami Early-Warning System Project

# Description
In March 2005, the Chinese Government and the Government of Indonesia signed a grant agreement for the Earthquake Observation and Measurement and Tsunami Early-Warning System Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) was the source of funding and it reportedly committed RMB 27 million in total.   The purpose of the project was to build an earthquake and tsunami early-warning system. The system consisted of 10 seismograph broadband and accelerometers and a national tsunami warning center. It involved station construction, equipment installation, technical services, spare parts maintenance, processing facilities, training, and expertise for a limited time to the Indonesian government. China Earthquake Administration was responsible for project implementation, which began in 2006 and ended in March 2009. The project was officially handed over to the Indonesian government on April 12, 2010.
justification: Project focuses on disaster early-warning systems without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Earthquake and tsunami early-warning system, seismograph equipment, national warning center, training and expertise transfer

title: China grants $1.5 million USD to Indonesia for Phase II of the Sotoli Hill Hospital Reconstruction Project
description: On 29 March 2005, an 8.7 magnitude earthquake hit Nias island, North Sumatra in Indonesia. It destroyed communities and valuable facilities including the local Sotoli Hill Hospital. In response, in 2005, the Chinese Government provided a $1.5 million USD grant to the Government of Indonesia's Aceh and Nias Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Agency for Phase II of the Sotoli Hill Hospital Reconstruction Project. The second phase of the construction, which was the phase funded by China, was completed on November 9, 2007.  On 2 April 2009, Phase II of the Sotoli Hill Hospital Reconstruction Project was officially complete. Works included the building of patient wards, laundry facilities, and a kitchen.
staff_comments: Also known as 索托利山医院 or Rumah Sakit Umum Daerah Gunungsitoli. The other phases of the hospital reconstruction were funded by Malaysia, Japan, and Singapore.
combined_text:
# Sector
RECONSTRUCTION RELIEF AND REHABILITATION

# Title
China grants $1.5 million USD to Indonesia for Phase II of the Sotoli Hill Hospital Reconstruction Project

# Description
On 29 March 2005, an 8.7 magnitude earthquake hit Nias island, North Sumatra in Indonesia. It destroyed communities and valuable facilities including the local Sotoli Hill Hospital. In response, in 2005, the Chinese Government provided a $1.5 million USD grant to the Government of Indonesia's Aceh and Nias Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Agency for Phase II of the Sotoli Hill Hospital Reconstruction Project. The second phase of the construction, which was the phase funded by China, was completed on November 9, 2007.  On 2 April 2009, Phase II of the Sotoli Hill Hospital Reconstruction Project was officially complete. Works included the building of patient wards, laundry facilities, and a kitchen.
justification: Project focuses on hospital reconstruction and rehabilitation, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Hospital reconstruction, patient wards, laundry facilities, kitchen construction

title: MOFCOM provides RMB 60 million grant for Aceh Tsunami Building Reconstruction Project
description: In 2005, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) provided an RMB 60 million ($7.5 million) grant for the Aceh Tsunami Building Reconstruction Project.  The purpose of this project was to construct 60 sets of prefabricated building in areas of Aceh Province that were affected by the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami. 34 buildings were constructed for schools. 17 buildings were constructed for kindergartens. 9 buildings were constructed for office space (including the campaign office for the Aceh Governor Elections).   China Construction Fourth Engineering Division Corp. Ltd (中建四局) — a subsidiary of China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC or 中国建筑集团有限公司) — was the contractor responsible for implementation.    The project commenced on December 12, 2005. Then, on November 30, 2006, MOFCOM dispatched 60 inspectors to conduct on-site project inspection work. The project was ultimately completed on December 12, 2006. An official project handover ceremony took place on December 21, 2006. A certificate of appreciation was issued by the Indonesian Government on March 6, 2008.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Aceh Tsunami Housing Project, the Indonesia Movable Building Assistance Project, and the Post-Tsunami Building Reconstruction Project. The Chinese project title is 亚齐海啸板房项目 or 中国援助亚齐海啸板房项目 or 印尼的60套预制板房.  Sources differ on the monetary value of the MOFCOM grant commitment for this project. One official source indicates that the value of the grant was RMB 60 million. One media source indicates that the value of the grant was 40 million. AidData relies on the estimate from the former rather than the latter. The Chinese Government contributed $63 million for tsunami relief in total (see Project ID#41811).
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
MOFCOM provides RMB 60 million grant for Aceh Tsunami Building Reconstruction Project

# Description
In 2005, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) provided an RMB 60 million ($7.5 million) grant for the Aceh Tsunami Building Reconstruction Project.  The purpose of this project was to construct 60 sets of prefabricated building in areas of Aceh Province that were affected by the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami. 34 buildings were constructed for schools. 17 buildings were constructed for kindergartens. 9 buildings were constructed for office space (including the campaign office for the Aceh Governor Elections).   China Construction Fourth Engineering Division Corp. Ltd (中建四局) — a subsidiary of China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC or 中国建筑集团有限公司) — was the contractor responsible for implementation.    The project commenced on December 12, 2005. Then, on November 30, 2006, MOFCOM dispatched 60 inspectors to conduct on-site project inspection work. The project was ultimately completed on December 12, 2006. An official project handover ceremony took place on December 21, 2006. A certificate of appreciation was issued by the Indonesian Government on March 6, 2008.
justification: Project focuses on post-disaster reconstruction of educational and administrative buildings, with no direct energy or environmental implications
evidence: Construction of schools, kindergartens, and office buildings in tsunami-affected areas, humanitarian grant nature

title: China donates 30 million Chinese Yuan worth of supplies to Indonesia for school construction in tsunami affected area
description: In 2005, China sent goods and materials to a tsunami-affected area in Indonesia, which were loaded into 535 standard containers. The shipment sailed from Tianjin on 7 March 2005. The supplies weigh approximately 7,000 tons and are worth about 30 million Chinese Yuan. The supplies were specifically requested by the Indonesian government to help build 60 schools. Each of the light-structure schools will be equipped with 15 classrooms, an independent shower, lighting and sanitary fittings and a bathroom. In August 2006, the Chinese government handed over the management of 28 of 60 school buildings to the local communities concerned.
combined_text:
# Sector
RECONSTRUCTION RELIEF AND REHABILITATION

# Title
China donates 30 million Chinese Yuan worth of supplies to Indonesia for school construction in tsunami affected area

# Description
In 2005, China sent goods and materials to a tsunami-affected area in Indonesia, which were loaded into 535 standard containers. The shipment sailed from Tianjin on 7 March 2005. The supplies weigh approximately 7,000 tons and are worth about 30 million Chinese Yuan. The supplies were specifically requested by the Indonesian government to help build 60 schools. Each of the light-structure schools will be equipped with 15 classrooms, an independent shower, lighting and sanitary fittings and a bathroom. In August 2006, the Chinese government handed over the management of 28 of 60 school buildings to the local communities concerned.
justification: Project focuses on school construction for social development in disaster-affected area, with no direct energy or environmental implications
evidence: Supplies for building 60 schools, focus on education infrastructure in tsunami-affected area

title: China sends 2nd International Search and Rescue Team (CISAR) to Indonesia as part of its Tsunami Relief efforts
description: On January 11, 2005, the second 35-people Chinese rescue team arrived in Banda Aceh with 150 drugs and 80 medical equipment worth 1.8 million RMB. 21 of the 35 members were medical personnel. The team returned to China on January 25.
staff_comments: To view other projects linked to China's contribution of 63 million USD for tsunami relief in total, see projects linked with resource #41811.

evidence: International search and rescue team, medical personnel and supplies, tsunami relief efforts

title: China Eximbank provides additional $68.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#34757)
description: In June 2004, China Eximbank and the Government Indonesia signed a memorandum of understanding regarding a loan for the  Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project. Then, on November 5, 2004, China Eximbank and the Government of Indonesia signed a $160.2 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement (#BLA04082) for the Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project (captured in Project ID#34757). The PBC carried the following borrowing terms: a maturity period of 15 years, a grace period of 7 years, and an interest rate of 3%. The proceeds from the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance an EPC contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which was signed on September 24, 2004.   On November 5, 2005, China Eximbank provided an additional $68.9 million to the Government of Indonesia for the Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project through an amendment to the PBC agreement that became effective on September 13, 2005. The additional PBC proceeds  were to be used by the borrower to partially finance a supplemental commercial (EPC) contract worth $83.453 million between CRBC and the Ministry of Public Works of Indonesia, which was signed on July 9, 2008.   The purpose of the project was to construct the 5.4 kilometer long, 30 meter wide bridge linking the city of Suramadu with Madura Island (exact locational coordinates: 7°11′3″S 112°46′49″E). It is the first bridge to cross the Madura Strait. The cable-stayed portion has three spans with lengths 192 meters (630 ft), 434 meters (1,424 ft), and 192 meters (630 ft). The bridge has two lanes in each direction plus an emergency lane and a dedicated lane for motorcycles in each direction. CRBC was the general (EPC) contractor responsible for implementation. However, China Harbor Engineering Co. Ltd. and a consortium of Indonesian companies, PT Adhi Karya and PT Waskita Karya, were also involved in implementation (most likely as subcontractors).   Construction began on November 19, 2005. The main span of Suramadu Bridge linking Surabaya in East Java mainland and Madura Island was connected successfully at midnight local time on Tuesday, March 31, 2009. The bridge was officially open to traffic on June 10, 2009. Within a week of the opening, it was discovered that nuts and bolts as well as maintenance lamps had been stolen and that there was evidence of vandalism of cables supporting the main span. As is often the case with public sector infrastructure facilities in Indonesia, there has been pressure to keep the tariffs for use of the bridge low. Tolls were initially set at Rp30,000 (USD $3 in 2009) for four-wheeled vehicles and Rp3,000 (USD $0.30) for two-wheelers. However, in early 2016, it was announced that President Jokowi favored a 50% cut in the tolls to help promote the competitiveness of industries on the Madura side of the bridge. On October 27, 2018, toll tariffs were abolished for all types of vehicles.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Suramadu Bridge Project or the Surabaya-Madura Bridge Project. The Chinese project title is 泗水－马都拉大桥 or 印尼泗水-马都拉大桥项目. 2. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.
combined_text:

# Description
In June 2004, China Eximbank and the Government Indonesia signed a memorandum of understanding regarding a loan for the  Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project. Then, on November 5, 2004, China Eximbank and the Government of Indonesia signed a $160.2 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) agreement (#BLA04082) for the Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project (captured in Project ID#34757). The PBC carried the following borrowing terms: a maturity period of 15 years, a grace period of 7 years, and an interest rate of 3%. The proceeds from the PBC were to be used by the borrower to partially finance an EPC contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which was signed on September 24, 2004.   On November 5, 2005, China Eximbank provided an additional $68.9 million to the Government of Indonesia for the Surabaya-Madura Island Bridge Construction Project through an amendment to the PBC agreement that became effective on September 13, 2005. The additional PBC proceeds  were to be used by the borrower to partially finance a supplemental commercial (EPC) contract worth $83.453 million between CRBC and the Ministry of Public Works of Indonesia, which was signed on July 9, 2008.   The purpose of the project was to construct the 5.4 kilometer long, 30 meter wide bridge linking the city of Suramadu with Madura Island (exact locational coordinates: 7°11′3″S 112°46′49″E). It is the first bridge to cross the Madura Strait. The cable-stayed portion has three spans with lengths 192 meters (630 ft), 434 meters (1,424 ft), and 192 meters (630 ft). However, China Harbor Engineering Co. Ltd. and a consortium of Indonesian companies, PT Adhi Karya and PT Waskita Karya, were also involved in implementation (most likely as subcontractors). However, in early 2016, it was announced that President Jokowi favored a 50% cut in the tolls to help promote the competitiveness of industries on the Madura side of the bridge. On October 27, 2018, toll tariffs were abolished for all types of vehicles.
justification: Bridge construction project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 5.4 km bridge construction, transportation infrastructure, no energy-related components

title: China donated $135,347 to World Health Organization to assess damage to Indonesia's health system after 2004 tsunami
description: In 2005, the Government of China donated $135,347 to the World Health Organization for Indonesia to assess the damage to the health system in areas affected by the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami. The project aimed to "assess the extent of damage to the overall health system in the disaster-affected area through rapid assessments of the conditions of infrastructure, essential equipment, human resources needs, and other essential system components such as the disease surveillance system, the drug supplies, and distribution systems and health systems management."  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #35247.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donated $135,347 to World Health Organization to assess damage to Indonesia's health system after 2004 tsunami

# Description
In 2005, the Government of China donated $135,347 to the World Health Organization for Indonesia to assess the damage to the health system in areas affected by the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami. The project aimed to "assess the extent of damage to the overall health system in the disaster-affected area through rapid assessments of the conditions of infrastructure, essential equipment, human resources needs, and other essential system components such as the disease surveillance system, the drug supplies, and distribution systems and health systems management."  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #35247.
justification: Project focuses on health system assessment and recovery following a natural disaster, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation to WHO for health system damage assessment, focus on infrastructure and human resources needs in disaster-affected area

title: China donated $169,184 to the World Health Organization to establish an integrated health emergency unit for disaster response in Indonesia after 2004 tsunami
description: In 2005, the Government of China donated $169,184 to the World Health Organization (WHO) to establish an Integrated Health Emergency Unit for Disaster Response in Indonesia in response to the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami. According to the WHO the aim of this project was to "establish a health emergency operations unit in Aceh and North Sumatra and also in Ministry of Health in Jakarta, including an integrated emergency health information system to coordinate health sector activities and health-related report."  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #35248.

evidence: Establishment of health emergency operations unit and information system for disaster response

title: China donated $541,389 to the World Health Organization for emergency health services in Indonesia in response to 2004 tsunami
description: In 2005, the Government of China donated $541,389 to the World Health Organization (WHO) for emergency health services in Aceh and North Sumatra in response to the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami. According to the WHO the aim of this project was to "organize public health campaigns for the prevention of disease outbreaks and for the treatment of prevalent diseases such as diarrhea, ARI, insect-borne diseases, and vaccine-preventable diseases through disease surveillance, organization of immunization campaigns, provision of treatment, and public health education."  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #35249.
combined_text:

According to the WHO the aim of this project was to "organize public health campaigns for the prevention of disease outbreaks and for the treatment of prevalent diseases such as diarrhea, ARI, insect-borne diseases, and vaccine-preventable diseases through disease surveillance, organization of immunization campaigns, provision of treatment, and public health education."  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #35249.

title: China donated $338,368 for emergency child and maternal health services in Indonesia after 2004 tsunami
description: In 2005, the Government of China donated $338,368 to the World Health Organization (WHO) for emergency child and maternal health services in Indonesia in response to the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami. According to the WHO, the aim of the project was to "assist the Government and other agencies in providing child and maternal health services. The focus will be given to technical support for the provision of care, preventive and treatment advice, training, and essential medical supplies."  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #35250.
